Engineering Mathematics-I.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100102
ğŸ“— Subject: Engineering Mathematics-I

ğŸ“š UNIT 1.0: Linear Algebra-I (7 hrs)
Elementary Row operations, Gauss-Jordan Method for finding the inverse of Matrix, Complex Matrix: Hermitian, Skew Hermitian and Unitary Matrix, Vector space, Sub Spaces, Linear dependence and Independences of Vectors, Linear Span, Basis, Dimension, Extension of basis of subspace, The rank of a matrix, Row and column space, Solvability of system of linear equations.

ğŸ“š UNIT 2.0: Linear Algebra-II (7 hrs)
Linear Transformations, Kernel and Range of linear transformation, Matrix Representation of a linear transformation, Rank-Nullity Theorem, Eigen Value and Eigen Vectors, Properties of Eigen vectors, Eigen Bases, Orthogonal Transformation, Similarity Transformation, Matrix Diagonalization, Cayley-Hamilton Theorem.

ğŸ“š UNIT 3.0: Calculus for Single Variable (7 hrs)
Indeterminate form, L'Hospital Rule, Rolle's Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, Expansion of function (single variable), Taylor and Maclaurin Series, Riemann Integration, Riemann Sum, Improper Integrals, Beta and Gamma function and their properties.

ğŸ“š UNIT 4.0: Multivariable Calculus (Differentiation) (7 hrs)
Function with two or more variable, Limit, continuity and Partial differentiation, Total Differentiation, Taylor's and Maclaurin's series for function with two variables, Jacobian, Maxima and Minima, Method of Lagrange's multiplier.

ğŸ“š UNIT 5.0: Multivariable Calculus (Integration) (7 hrs)
Double Integral, change of order of integration, Triple integral, Change of Variable in a Double and Triple Integrals, Change to polar coordinate, Change to cylindrical coordinate, Change to spherical polar coordinate, Application to area and volume using double and triple integral.

ğŸ“š UNIT 6.0: Vector Calculus (7 hrs)
Scalar and vector fields, Gradient, Directional derivative, Divergence, Curl and their properties, Line integral, Green's theorem in plane (without proof), Surface integral, Stoke's theorem (without proof), Volume Integral, Gauss-Divergence theorem (without proof).

ğŸ“˜ TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Mathematics-I â€“ Reena Garg, Khanna Book Publishing, ISBN: 9391505171
2. Advanced Engineering Mathematics â€“ Chandrika Prasad & Reena Garg, ISBN: 9789386173522
3. Higher Engineering Mathematics â€“ B.V. Ramana, Tata McGraw Hill, ISBN: 9780070634190
4. Advanced Engineering Mathematics â€“ S.R.K. Iyengar, R.K. Jain, Narosa, ISBN: 9788184875607
5. Advanced Engineering Mathematics â€“ Erwin Kreyszig, 9th Ed., John Wiley & Sons, 2006

Engineering Physics.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100110
ğŸ“— Subject: Engineering Physics

ğŸ“š UNIT 1.0

1ï¸âƒ£ Frame of Reference: 2 hrs
Non-Inertial frame of reference, rotating coordinate system, centripetal and Coriolis acceleration and its application in weather system.

2ï¸âƒ£ Oscillations: 3 hrs
Harmonic Oscillator, Damped Harmonic motion - overdamped, critically damped and lightly damped oscillators, Forced Oscillators and Resonance.

ğŸ“š UNIT 2.0

1ï¸âƒ£ Optics: 4 hrs
Huygens's Principle, Superposition of Waves and interference of Light by wave front splitting and amplitude-splitting; Young's double slit experiment, Michelson interferometer, Fraunhofer diffraction from single slit and circular aperture, Diffraction Grating and their resolving power.

2ï¸âƒ£ LASER: 4 hrs
Einstein's theory of matter-radiations interaction, Einstein's Coefficients (A and B), Amplification by population inversion, Different types of lasers - Gas Laser, Helium-Neon Laser, Solid State Laser (Ruby, Neodymium), Semiconductor Laser.

ğŸ“š UNIT 3.0

1ï¸âƒ£ Quantum Mechanics: 5 hrs
Compton Effect, Photoelectric Effect, Wave Particle duality, de Broglie's hypothesis, Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle, Wave function and wave packets, phase and group velocities, Schrodinger's Wave Equation, Normalization, Expectation values, Eigenvalues and Eigenfunction.

2ï¸âƒ£ Applications in One Dimension: 2 hrs
Application of Schrodinger Wave Equation for particle in one dimensional box - its wavefunction and eigenvalue of energy and momentum.

ğŸ“š UNIT 4.0

1ï¸âƒ£ Vector Calculus: 2 hrs
Gradient, Divergence and Curl, Line, Surface and Volume integrals, Gauss's Divergence theorem and Stokes' theorem in Cartesian Coordinate.

2ï¸âƒ£ Electrostatics: 4 hrs
Gauss's Law and its applications, Divergence and Curl of Electrostatic fields, Electrostatic Potential, Boundary Conditions, Poisson's and Laplace's equations, Dielectrics, Polarization, Bound Charges, Electric displacement, Boundary Conditions in dielectrics.

ğŸ“š UNIT 5.0

1ï¸âƒ£ Magnetostatics: 4 hrs
Lorentz force, Biot-Savart and Ampere's circuital laws and their applications, Divergence and Curl of Magneto static fields, Magnetic vector potential, Force and torque on a magnetic dipole, Magnetic Materials, Magnetization, Bound currents, Boundary conditions.

2ï¸âƒ£ Electrodynamics and Electromagnetic Waves: 4 hrs
Ohm's law, Motional EMF, Faraday's Law, Lenz's law, Self and mutual inductance, Energy stored in magnetic field, Maxwell's equations in vacuum and nonconducting medium, Continuity Equation, Poynting Theorem, Wave Equations: plane electromagnetic wave in vacuum and their transverse nature and Polarization.

ğŸ“š UNIT 6.0

1ï¸âƒ£ Introduction to Solids and Semiconductors: 3 hrs
Free electron theory of metal, Fermi level, Bloch's theorem for particle in a periodic Potential, Kroning-Penney model and origin of energy band.

2ï¸âƒ£ Electronic Materials: 3 hrs
Metals, semiconductors and insulators, intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductors, Carrier transport, diffusion and drift, P-N junction.

ğŸ“˜ TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Quantum Physics â€“ R. Eisberg, R. Resnick (Wiley India)
2. Theory of Vibration â€“ W.T. Thomson, M.D. Dahleh (Pearson)
3. Introduction to Electrodynamics â€“ D.J. Griffiths (Pearson)
4. Electromagnetism â€“ I.S. Grant, W.R. Phillips (Wiley)
5. The Feynman Lectures â€“ R.P. Feynman, R.B. Leighton (Pearson)
6. Optics â€“ Ajay Ghatak (McGraw Hill)
7. Physics of Vibration and Waves â€“ H.J. Pain (Wiley)
8. Concept of Modern Physics â€“ Arthur Beiser (McGraw Hill)
9. Introduction to Solid State Physics â€“ C. Kittel (Wiley)

Engineering Physics Lab.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100110P
ğŸ“— Subject: Engineering Physics Lab

ğŸ“š Perform any 10 Experiments:

1ï¸âƒ£ Determination of the capacitance and permittivity of the given material.
2ï¸âƒ£ Determination of e/m of electron.
3ï¸âƒ£ Determination of Planck's constant and Photoelectric Work Function using Photoelectric cell.
4ï¸âƒ£ Verification of inverse square law using photocell.
5ï¸âƒ£ Determination of Wavelength of (He-Ne) LASER using Diffraction Grating Method.
6ï¸âƒ£ Calculation of Energy Band Gap of a semiconductor.
7ï¸âƒ£ Determination of Dielectric constant using resonance method.
8ï¸âƒ£ Determination of Wavelength of Sodium light by measuring the diameter of the Newton's Ring.
9ï¸âƒ£ Determination of curvature of convex surface of a lens by Newton's ring.
ğŸ”Ÿ Verification of existence of Bohr's Energy level with Frank-Hertz apparatus.
1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Determination of the Earth's horizontal magnetic field intensity and magnetic Moment of a magnet by employing magnetometer.
1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£ Verification of Faraday's Law and Lenz's Law of Electromagnetic Induction.

Programming for Problem Solving.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100111
ğŸ“— Subject: Programming for Problem Solving

ğŸ“š UNIT 1.0 (6 hrs)
Introduction to Programming: Components of a computer system (disks, memory, processor, where a program is stored and executed, operating system, compilers etc.). Idea of Algorithm: Steps to solve logical and numerical problems. Representation of Algorithm: Flowchart/Pseudo code with examples. From algorithms to programs; source code, variables (with data types), variables and memory locations, Syntax and Logical Errors in compilation, object and executable code.

ğŸ“š UNIT 2.0 (8 hrs)
Operators, Conditional Branching and Loops: Arithmetic expressions/arithmetic operators, relational operators, logical operators, bitwise operators and precedence. Writing and evaluation of conditionals and consequent branching, Iteration and loops.

ğŸ“š UNIT 3.0 (6 hrs)
Arrays and Strings: Array declaration & initialization, bound checking, arrays (1-D, 2-D), character arrays and strings.

ğŸ“š UNIT 4.0 (9 hrs)
Functions, Recursion and Pointers: Functions (including using built-in libraries), Parameter passing in functions, call by value, passing arrays to functions. Recursion with examples like factorial, Fibonacci, Ackermann function. Pointers: Defining pointers, Use of pointers in self-referential structures, idea of call by reference.

ğŸ“š UNIT 5.0 (8 hrs)
User Defined Data Types and File Handling: Structure - defining, declaring, initializing; accessing structure members, array of structures, nested structures, structure and function, typedef. Union - definition, declaration, accessing members. File handling - opening/closing a file, text and binary files, I/O operations, error handling, random access to files.

ğŸ“š UNIT 6.0 (5 hrs)
Basic Algorithms: Searching, Basic Sorting Algorithms (Bubble, Insertion and Selection), Finding roots of equations, notion of order of complexity through example programs (no formal definition required).

ğŸ“˜ TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Programming in ANSI C, E. Balagurusamy, McGraw Hill, 7th Ed., ISBN: 9789339219666
2. The C Programming Language, Kernighan & Ritchie, Pearson, 2nd Ed., ISBN: 9789332549449
3. Computer Fundamentals and Programming in C, Reema Thareja, Oxford University Press, 3rd Ed., ISBN: 9789354977893

Programming for Problem Solving Lab.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100111P
ğŸ“— Subject: Programming for Problem Solving Lab

ğŸ“š Perform any 10 Experiments:

1ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 1: Problem solving using computers
Lab 1: Familiarization with programming environment

2ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 2: Variable types and type conversions
Lab 2: Simple computational problems using arithmetic expressions

3ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 3: Branching and logical expressions
Lab 3: Problems involving if-then-else structures

4ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 4: Loops, while and for loops
Lab 4: Iterative problems e.g., sum of series

5ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 5: 1D Arrays: searching, sorting
Lab 5: 1D Array manipulation

6ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 6: 2D arrays and Strings
Lab 6: Matrix problems, String operations

7ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 7: Functions, call by value
Lab 7: Simple functions

8ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 8 & 9: Numerical methods (Root finding, numerical differentiation, numerical integration)
Lab 8 and 9: Programming for solving numerical methods problems

9ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 10: Recursion, structure of recursive calls
Lab 10: Recursive functions

ğŸ”Ÿ Tutorial 11: Pointers, structures and dynamic memory allocation
Lab 11: Pointers and structures

1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Tutorial 12: File handling
Lab 12: File operations

BASIC ELECTRONICS ENGG..text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100114
ğŸ“— Subject: BASIC ELECTRONICS ENGG.

ğŸ“š UNIT 1.0: Semiconductor Diode (9 hrs)
Intrinsic and extrinsic types, energy band in intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductor, equilibrium carrier concentration, direct and indirect band-gap semiconductor. Ideal diode construction, p-n junction under open circuit, drift and diffusion current, built-in potential, forward bias and reverse bias condition. Effect of temperature, static and dynamic resistance, breakdown mechanism in diode, junction capacitance. Zener diode working, VI characteristics, Light Emitting Diode, Photodiode, Solar Cell.

ğŸ“š UNIT 2.0: Diode Applications (7 hrs)
Half wave rectifiers, full wave rectifiers & rectifier with filters, Zener diode application as voltage regulator, clipping and clamping circuits, voltage doubler (includes numerical on rectifier, filter, and Zener regulator).

ğŸ“š UNIT 3.0: Bipolar Junction Transistor (8 hrs)
BJT introduction: Construction, symbol, and types (PNP and NPN), working of BJT, BJT configuration and characteristics, load line analysis, operating point, need for biasing, different biasing circuits, bias stability. BJT as a switch & amplifier, low frequency small signal model of BJT, CE amplifier with and without feedback.

ğŸ“š UNIT 4.0: Field Effect Transistor (6 hrs)
General characteristics of FET; comparison between FET & BJT; JFET: construction, principle of operation, Shockley equation, output and transfer characteristics. Depletion & Enhancement Type MOSFET: construction, principle of operation, output and transfer characteristics.

ğŸ“š UNIT 5.0: Operational Amplifier (6 hrs)
Block diagram of an operational amplifier, schematic symbol, characteristics of an ideal and practical operational amplifier, concept of virtual ground, inverting and non-inverting amplifier, voltage follower, adder, subtractor, integrator and differentiator.

ğŸ“š UNIT 6.0: Fundamentals of Digital Electronics (6 hrs)
Introduction to number system: octal, hexadecimal, binary numbers, binary addition using 1's and 2's complement method. Logic gates, universal gates, Boolean algebra, De Morgan's theorems, simplification and realization of Boolean expression using basic gates and NAND gates.

ğŸ“˜ TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Electronic Device & Circuit Theory â€“ Boylestad and Nashelsky (Pearson)
2. Electronic Principles â€“ Albert Malvino & David J. Bates (TMH)
3. Digital Logic and Computer Design â€“ M. Morris Mano (PHI)
4. Electronic Devices and Circuit â€“ David A. Bell (Oxford)
5. Microelectronic Circuits: Theory and Application â€“ Sedra and Smith (Oxford)

Basic Electronics Engg. Lab.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100114P
ğŸ“— Subject: Basic Electronics Engg. Lab

ğŸ“š Perform any 10 Experiments:

1ï¸âƒ£ Study of Cathode Ray Oscilloscope (CRO)
(a) Measurement of amplitude, time period and frequency of unknown continuous signals.

2ï¸âƒ£ Identification of active and passive components.

3ï¸âƒ£ Study the characteristics of P-N junction diode under:
(a) Forward bias
(b) Reverse bias

4ï¸âƒ£ Study of clipping circuits and clamping circuits.

5ï¸âƒ£ Construct a half-wave and full-wave rectifier using sinusoidal voltage.

6ï¸âƒ£ Study of full wave rectifier using capacitor filter.

7ï¸âƒ£ Construct voltage regulator using Zener diode.

8ï¸âƒ£ Study the input/output characteristics of Common Base (CB) BJT.

9ï¸âƒ£ Study the input/output characteristics of Common Emitter (CE) BJT.

ğŸ”Ÿ Study the output and transfer characteristics of JFET.

1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Study of operational amplifier as:
(i) Inverting
(ii) Non-inverting amplifier

1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£ Study of operational amplifier as:
(i) Integrator
(ii) Differentiator

(a) NOR gate
(b) NAND gate

Swachha Bharat Mission (SBM).text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100215P
ğŸ“— Subject: Swachha Bharat Mission (SBM)

ğŸ“š OBJECTIVES:
1ï¸âƒ£ Understanding the importance of cleanliness and sanitation: Awareness about personal health, environmental sustainability, and community well-being. Includes waste management, sanitation practices, and public health impact.

2ï¸âƒ£ Developing skills for effective waste management: Techniques such as segregation, composting, recycling, hazardous waste disposal, reducing waste, and sustainable practices.

3ï¸âƒ£ Promoting behavioural change towards cleanliness: Encouraging hygiene, anti-littering, anti-open defecation, and responsible disposal habits.

4ï¸âƒ£ Creating awareness about Swachh Bharat Mission initiatives: Information about government initiatives like Swachh Survekshan, Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, Clean India Campaign, progress, and challenges.

5ï¸âƒ£ Engaging in community participation and advocacy: Tools for engaging with communities, promoting sanitation, and advocating policy improvements at various levels.

ğŸ“š PRE-REQUISITE: Nil

ğŸ“š COURSE OUTCOMES:
1ï¸âƒ£ Increased awareness and knowledge about cleanliness, hygiene, waste management, and SBM initiatives.
2ï¸âƒ£ Enhanced skills in segregation, composting, recycling, and sustainable practices.
3ï¸âƒ£ Behavioral shift towards personal and public cleanliness.
4ï¸âƒ£ Greater involvement in community-led cleanliness drives and policy advocacy.
5ï¸âƒ£ Active contribution to SBM goals and campaigns.

ğŸ“š REPORT:
- Submission of reports on any topic related to Swachh Bharat Mission.

IT WORKSHOP.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100113
ğŸ“— Subject: IT WORKSHOP

ğŸ“š UNIT 1.0: PC HARDWARE (6 lectures)
Identification of the peripherals of a computer, components in a CPU and its functions. Block diagram of the CPU along with the configuration of each peripheral. Functions of Motherboard. Assembling and Disassembling of PC. Installation of OS. Basic Linux commands.

ğŸ“š UNIT 2.0: INTERNET (4 lectures)
Web Browsers, Access of websites, Surfing the Web, Search Engines, Customization of web browsers, proxy settings, bookmarks, search toolbars, pop-up blockers. Antivirus types, Protection from various threats.

ğŸ“š UNIT 3.0: MICROSOFT WORD (4 lectures)
Overview of MS Word features. Usage of Hyperlink, Symbols, Spell Check, Track Changes. Table of Content, Newspaper columns, Images from files and clipart, Drawing toolbar and Word Art, Formatting Images, Textboxes, Paragraphs and Mail Merge in Word. Using Word to create Project Certificate, Project Abstract, News Letter, Resume.

ğŸ“š UNIT 4.0: LaTeX (6 lectures)
Word Orientation: Overview of LaTeX and tool Word: Importance of LaTeX and MS Office or equivalent (FOSS) tool Word as word Processors. Details of the four tasks and features that would be covered in each. Using LaTeX and Word - Accessing, overview of toolbars, saving files, Using help and resources, rulers, format painter. Using LaTeX and Word to create a project certificate. Features: Formatting Fonts, Drop Cap, Text effects, Character Spacing, Borders and Colors, Inserting Header and Footer, Using Date and Time, Formatting Styles, Inserting table, Bullets and Numbering, Changing Text Direction, Cell alignment, Footnote, Hyperlink, Symbols, Spell Check, Track Changes. Creating a Newsletter: Table of Content, Newspaper columns, Images, Drawing toolbar, Word Art, Textboxes, Paragraphs, Mail Merge.

ğŸ“š UNIT 5.0: MICROSOFT EXCEL (4 lectures)
Overview of Excel Features, Excel formulae & Functions, Conditional formatting, Charts, Hyperlinking, Renaming and Inserting worksheets, Data Analysis functions. Creating a Scheduler: Gridlines, Format Cells, Summation, auto fill, Formatting. Calculating GPA: Cell Referencing, Formulae and functions in Excel.

ğŸ“š UNIT 6.0: MICROSOFT POWERPOINT (4 lectures)
Overview of PowerPoint features, Insertion of images, slide transition, Custom animation, Hyperlinks.

ğŸ“˜ TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. The Complete Computer Upgrade and Repair Book â€“ Cheryl A. Schmidt, 3rd Ed., Wiley Dreamtech
2. Introduction to Information Technology â€“ ITL Education Solutions Limited, Pearson Education
3. PC Hardware A Handbook â€“ Kate J. Chase, PHI
4. LaTeX Beginner's Guide â€“ Stefan Kottwitz, Packt Publishing

IT WORKSHOP LAB.text:
ğŸ“˜ COURSE CODE: 100113P
ğŸ“— Subject: IT WORKSHOP LAB

ğŸ“š UNIT 1 â€“ PC Hardware
ğŸ”¹ Task 1: Identify the peripherals of a computer, components in a CPU and its functions. Different types of printer.
ğŸ”¹ Task 2: Every student should disassemble and assemble the PC back to working condition. Lab instructors should verify the work and follow it up with a Viva. Also students need to go through the video which shows the process of assembling a PC.

ğŸ“š UNIT 2 â€“ Operating System Installation
ğŸ”¹ Task 1: Every student should individually install MS Windows on the personal computer. Lab instructor should verify the installation and follow it up with a Viva.
ğŸ”¹ Task 2: Every student should install Linux on the computer. The system should be configured as dual boot with both Windows and Linux. Lab instructors should verify the installation and follow it up with a Viva.
ğŸ”¹ Task 3: Practice and usage of different commands of DOS and Linux.

ğŸ“š UNIT 3 â€“ Internet & World Wide Web
ğŸ”¹ Task 1: Orientation & Connectivity Boot Camp: Configure TCP/IP settings, access the internet or simulate WWW on LAN.
ğŸ”¹ Task 2: Web Browsers and Surfing: Set up LAN proxy, bookmarks, search toolbars, pop-up blockers, install plugins like Flash and JRE.
ğŸ”¹ Task 3: Search Engines & Netiquette: Practice searching on topics using Google; demonstrate results.
ğŸ”¹ Task 4: Cyber Hygiene: Configure browsers to block pop-ups, avoid ActiveX downloads, and protect against viruses/worms.

ğŸ“š UNIT 4 â€“ LaTeX
ğŸ”¹ Task 1: Word Orientation â€“ Introduction to LaTeX and Word processors (MS Word or FOSS alternative), toolbars, saving, and formatting.
ğŸ”¹ Task 2: Create a project certificate. Topics include fonts, drop caps, text effects, spacing, borders, headers, footers, and date/time insertion.
ğŸ”¹ Task 3: Create a project abstract â€“ Work with styles, tables, bullets/numbering, direction, alignment, footnotes, hyperlinks, symbols, spelling, track changes.
ğŸ”¹ Task 4: Create a newsletter â€“ Work with TOC, columns, images, drawing tools, WordArt, formatting, textboxes, paragraphs, and Mail Merge.

ğŸ“š UNIT 5 â€“ Excel
ğŸ”¹ Task 1: Create a Scheduler â€“ Gridlines, format cells, summation, autofill, and text formatting.
ğŸ”¹ Task 2: GPA Calculation â€“ Cell referencing, formulas (average, std dev), charts, sheets, hyperlinks, count, VLOOKUP/LOOKUP.
ğŸ”¹ Task 3: Use split cells, freeze panes, grouping, sorting, Boolean/logical operators, and conditional formatting.

ğŸ“š UNIT 6 â€“ PowerPoint
ğŸ”¹ Task 1: Basic PowerPoint â€“ Orientation, layouts, inserting text, WordArt, text formatting, bullets/numbering, shapes, lines/arrows.
ğŸ”¹ Task 2: Interactive Presentations â€“ Insert images, audio/video, clipart, objects, tables, and charts.
ğŸ”¹ Task 3: Master Layouts and Views â€“ Slide templates, notes, presentation views, backgrounds, textures, design templates, hidden slides.
